revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-02 16:47:14.000000000', 'message': "Fix systemd warnings around executable and world-inaccessible bits

Right now we get the following warnings in the journal:
Apr 02 10:47:48 controller-1.localdomain systemd[1]: Configuration file /usr/lib/systemd/system/tripleo-container-shutdown.service is marked executable. Please remove executable permission bits. Proceeding anyway.
Apr 02 10:47:48 controller-1.localdomain systemd[1]: Configuration file /usr/lib/systemd/system/tripleo-container-shutdown.service is marked world-inaccessible. This has no effect as configuration data is accessible via APIs without restrictions. Proceeding anyway.
Apr 02 10:47:48 controller-1.localdomain systemd[1]: Configuration file /usr/lib/systemd/system/netns-placeholder.service is marked executable. Please remove executable permission bits. Proceeding anyway.
Apr 02 10:47:48 controller-1.localdomain systemd[1]: Configuration file /usr/lib/systemd/system/netns-placeholder.service is marked world-inaccessible. This has no effect as configuration data is accessible via APIs without restrictions. Proceeding anyway.

Let's make the two services 0644 so that these warnings go away.
While we're at it we make 0644 also the preset files as ours are
the only ones with a non 0644 permission:
[root@ctrl-1-0 system-preset]# ls -l /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/
total 28
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root  264 Oct 29 20:09 85-display-manager.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 3982 Oct 29 20:09 90-default.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root  951 Jun 22  2018 90-systemd.preset
-rwx------. 1 root root   33 Mar 30 07:50 91-netns-placeholder.preset
-rwx------. 1 root root   42 Mar 30 07:50 91-tripleo-container-shutdown.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root   10 Oct 29 20:09 99-default-disable.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root   30 Jan 11 10:17 fwupd-refresh.preset

Change-Id: Ib0de0a516504d542a0f01ee40129e139a5709c33
"}]
commit_message:
Fix systemd warnings around executable and world-inaccessible bits

Right now we get the following warnings in the journal:
Apr 02 10:47:48 controller-1.localdomain systemd[1]: Configuration file /usr/lib/systemd/system/tripleo-container-shutdown.service is marked executable. Please remove executable permission bits. Proceeding anyway.
Apr 02 10:47:48 controller-1.localdomain systemd[1]: Configuration file /usr/lib/systemd/system/tripleo-container-shutdown.service is marked world-inaccessible. This has no effect as configuration data is accessible via APIs without restrictions. Proceeding anyway.
Apr 02 10:47:48 controller-1.localdomain systemd[1]: Configuration file /usr/lib/systemd/system/netns-placeholder.service is marked executable. Please remove executable permission bits. Proceeding anyway.
Apr 02 10:47:48 controller-1.localdomain systemd[1]: Configuration file /usr/lib/systemd/system/netns-placeholder.service is marked world-inaccessible. This has no effect as configuration data is accessible via APIs without restrictions. Proceeding anyway.

Let's make the two services 0644 so that these warnings go away.
While we're at it we make 0644 also the preset files as ours are
the only ones with a non 0644 permission:
[root@ctrl-1-0 system-preset]# ls -l /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/
total 28
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root  264 Oct 29 20:09 85-display-manager.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 3982 Oct 29 20:09 90-default.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root  951 Jun 22  2018 90-systemd.preset
-rwx------. 1 root root   33 Mar 30 07:50 91-netns-placeholder.preset
-rwx------. 1 root root   42 Mar 30 07:50 91-tripleo-container-shutdown.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root   10 Oct 29 20:09 99-default-disable.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root   30 Jan 11 10:17 fwupd-refresh.preset

Change-Id: Ib0de0a516504d542a0f01ee40129e139a5709c33

'}, {'created': '2019-04-16 03:06:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add test for check dependencies between incr backups

Because of f7409cdb429a55d8a6ea766ae4dc124fae76106f
we realize that we need more coverage over the
incremental backup.

One of the main problems we had was creating multiple
incremental for differents full backups.

Steps:
1. create a volume
2. create a first full backup
3. create 2 incremental backups from the first full backup
4. create a second full backup
5. create an incremental backup from the second full backup
6. delete the last incremental, the second backup and the
last incremental for the first backup
7. Check that you can‚Äôt delete the first full backup

commit_message:
Add test for check dependencies between incr backups

One of the main problems we had was creating multiple
incremental for differents full backups.

Steps:
1. create a volume
2. create a first full backup
3. create 2 incremental backups from the first full backup
4. create a second full backup
5. create an incremental backup from the second full backup
6. delete the last incremental, the second backup and the
last incremental for the first backup
7. Check that you can‚Äôt delete the first full backup

Change-Id: I0e01defa4195007b6b3dda5b80571f042e273eae

commit_message:
Update python-dracclient version

Update python-dracclient version to indicate Wallaby compatibility with
6.*.* releases.

Version 6.0.0 is available from PyPI [1].

[1] https://pypi.org/project/python-dracclient/6.0.0/

commit_message:
Volume retype with migrations and encryption tests

- First scenario: retype unencrypted volume to LUKS type.
- Second scenario: retype encrypted LUKS volume to regular type.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/779114
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-cinderclient/+/779110
Partial-Bug: #1687880
Implements: blueprint sizing-encrypted-volumes
Change-Id: Ia8e634717eb11791048b15769a011530594dd211

commit_message:
Don't update status for replaced resource

With I04e7ad90944c2d03ce0e59ba16af9d60d6e01222 we allowed
update of previously-existing resource if replacement
creation has failed during last update. However, we force
update the status of the existing resource to 'COMPLETE'.
Therefore, in the next update if properties/type has not
changed for the resource it won't try to update/replace
the previously existing resource resulting in false positive
of stack updated successfully.

Task: 42194
Change-Id: Icc90a921ec67e49aec2c4acfad72235c57c78421
(cherry picked from commit bfbaab107d709c37548a22239b952c6221b9ac85)

commit_message:
Workaround for new pip 20.3 behavior

This WA set specific pip version to avoid the issue:
"ERROR: Links are not allowed as constraints" [1]
A proper fix would be to adapt to new pip behavior.
Similar issue on Devstack [2][3]

[1] https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/8210
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/devstack/+bug/1906322
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/764803

Change-Id: I49d436b0cf1503b148a04f82e1ee41941ebd9d0a
(cherry picked from commit a93e1cc9798473dcaac748719da8ab5f0648ebc0)

commit_message:
masakari: fix minor issues with instance monitor

* Don't generate masakari.conf for instance monitor
* Don't generate masakari-monitors.conf for API or engine
* Use a consistent name for dimensions -
  masakari_instancemonitor_dimensions
* Fix source code paths in dev mode

Change-Id: I551f93c9bf1ad6712b53c316074ae1df84e4352b

commit_message:
container-images: fix Cinder when running at Edge

When Cinder Volume is running at the Edge, we need to support the
OS::TripleO::Services::CinderVolumeEdge service; as well as the
ContainerCinderConfigImage parameter for the Cinder Volume, since it
only used to be added for Cinder API but Cinder API is disabled at the
Edge.

Closes-Bug: #1920704
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I1e94668978fbf1dc928b6af50a404e6c687707da
(cherry picked from commit 8dc6dfe488439b26db5eec1ae63ef77322bc3787)

commit_message:
container-images: fix Cinder when running at Edge

When Cinder Volume is running at the Edge, we need to support the
OS::TripleO::Services::CinderVolumeEdge service; as well as the
ContainerCinderConfigImage parameter for the Cinder Volume, since it
only used to be added for Cinder API but Cinder API is disabled at the
Edge.

Closes-Bug: #1920704
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I1e94668978fbf1dc928b6af50a404e6c687707da
(cherry picked from commit 8dc6dfe488439b26db5eec1ae63ef77322bc3787)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-06 15:50:13.000000000', 'message': 'healthcheck_port: drop lsof in favor of awk/find

It seems lsof is a bit too heavy on the system when multiple
healthchecks are running in parallel.
So instead of calling a "big" process, let's split a bit things and get
to the filesystem directly in order to pick only the things we actually
need.

What changes:
- using /proc/net/{tcp,udp}, we get every socket matching the port
- using find with the right options, we can ensure at least one socket
  exists with the wanted inode(s)

The last part exits as soon as we have a match in order to make it
faster and less resource consuming.

Change-Id: I64776992a7e457781aa8ddaba359ef085d4cb77d
Partial-Bug: #1921714

commit_message:
healthcheck_port: drop lsof in favor of awk/find

It seems lsof is a bit too heavy on the system when multiple
healthchecks are running in parallel.
So instead of calling a "big" process, let's split a bit things and get
to the filesystem directly in order to pick only the things we actually
need.

What changes:
- using /proc/net/{tcp,udp}, we get every socket matching the port
- using find with the right options, we can ensure at least one socket
  exists with the wanted inode(s)

The last part exits as soon as we have a match in order to make it
faster and less resource consuming.

Change-Id: I64776992a7e457781aa8ddaba359ef085d4cb77d
Partial-Bug: #1921714

commit_message:
Add secure-rbac tests for SecretStores API

This patch adds basic RBAC test for the Secret Stores API for
the reader, member and admin personas with project scope.

The tests are skipped by a config option, as they require
the multiple-backends feature to be enabled in barbican.

The devstack instace we're using for gate tests does not have
this enabled, so we default to False for now.

Change-Id: Ibca9d44fb3d0f4fd9945a7e6c636e0fbf6beb42e

commit_message:
Re-enable Docker Zuul jobs

Docker Zuul jobs were disabled previously because Wallaby u-c were
not yet ready.

commit_message:
Add ussuri to check queue as non-voting

This gives us a test run against Ceph on
bionic nodes to help prevent regression against
older kernels (rbd map).

Related-Bug: #1921897
Change-Id: I2840c2d5f3d0f65e8f66ed9a803ea0f26d10f316

commit_message:
Support bypassing Monasca Log API for control plane logs

This change allows a user to forward control plane logs
directly to Elasticsearch from Fluentd, rather than via
the Monasca Log API when Monasca is enabled. The Monasca
Log API can continue to handle tenant logs.

For many use cases this is simpler, reduces resource
consumption and helps to decouple control plane logging
services from tenant logging services.

It may not always be desired, so is optional and off by
default.

Change-Id: I195e8e4b73ca8f573737355908eb30a3ef13b0d6

subject: Adds support for creating projects by ID and extends mapping engine. (second try)
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-02 10:04:06.000000000', 'message': 'Adds support for creating projects by ID and extends mapping engine.
(second try)

Currently mapping engine can map multiple projects for user (as stated in https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/pike/advanced-topics/federation/mapping_combinations.html), but this support
lacks from (a) dynamic mapping projects from assertion (for ex. projects ids are in assertion) and (b) mapping engine cannot map to list from assertion (if in asertion we have
"some_field": [ id1, id2, ..., idN ] - then using this field by substitution - eg "{1}" wont map this to whole needed structure of projects in mapping).

In patch I extend mapping schema by adding new field "projects_spec" of type string.
This field contains string formated like

  project1ID:role1:role2:..:roleN,project2ID:role1:...:roleN,...

and this is mapped into proper structure { "projects": [  { "id": .., "roles": [ ... ] }, ... ] }
this allows the identity provider to supply permission-like informations about what projects user should have access to.

Also new configuration options has been added to more precisely control behavior of auto-provisioned projects.

Change-Id: Ic80e7f8b80503b2ffa8fad38b483f01000b6ac2e
'}, {'created': '2021-04-07 14:42:45.000000000', 'message': 'Adds support for creating projects by ID and extends mapping engine.

In patch I extend mapping schema by adding new field "projects_spec" of type string.
This field contains string formated like

  project1ID:role1:role2:..:roleN,project2ID:role1:...:roleN,...

and this is mapped into proper structure { "projects": [  { "id": .., "roles": [ ... ] }, ... ] }
this allows the identity provider to supply permission-like informations about what projects user should have access to.

Also new configuration options has been added to more precisely control behavior of auto-provisioned projects.

Change-Id: Ic80e7f8b80503b2ffa8fad38b483f01000b6ac2e
'}]
commit_message:
Adds support for creating projects by ID and extends mapping engine.
(second try)

Currently mapping engine can map multiple projects for user (as stated in https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/pike/advanced-topics/federation/mapping_combinations.html), but this support
lacks from (a) dynamic mapping projects from assertion (for ex. projects ids are in assertion) and (b) mapping engine cannot map to list from assertion (if in asertion we have
"some_field": [ id1, id2, ..., idN ] - then using this field by substitution - eg "{1}" wont map this to whole needed structure of projects in mapping).

In patch I extend mapping schema by adding new field "projects_spec" of type string.
This field contains string formated like

  project1ID:role1:role2:..:roleN,project2ID:role1:...:roleN,...

and this is mapped into proper structure { "projects": [  { "id": .., "roles": [ ... ] }, ... ] }
this allows the identity provider to supply permission-like informations about what projects user should have access to.

Also new configuration options has been added to more precisely control behavior of auto-provisioned projects.

Change-Id: Ic80e7f8b80503b2ffa8fad38b483f01000b6ac2e

[{'created': '2021-01-08 10:10:07.000000000', 'message': 'Disable Monasca Log Metrics service by default

The Log Metrics service is an admin only service. We now have
support in Fluentd via the Prometheus plugin to create metrics
from logs. These metrics can be scraped into Monasca or Prometheus.
It therefore makes sense to deprecate this service, starting by
disabling it by default, and then removing it after the X release.
This should improve the stability of the Monasca metrics pipeline
by ensuring that all metrics pass via the Monasca API for
validation, and ensure that metrics generated from logs are
available to both Prometheus and Monasca users by default.

commit_message:
Disable Monasca Log Metrics service by default

The Log Metrics service is an admin only service. We now have
support in Fluentd via the Prometheus plugin to create metrics
from logs. These metrics can be scraped into Monasca or Prometheus.
It therefore makes sense to deprecate this service, starting by
disabling it by default, and then removing it in the Xena release.
This should improve the stability of the Monasca metrics pipeline
by ensuring that all metrics pass via the Monasca API for
validation, and ensure that metrics generated from logs are
available to both Prometheus and Monasca users by default.

Change-Id: I704feb4434c1eece3eb00c19dc5f934fd4bc27b4

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-25 09:27:59.000000000', 'message': 'HA: fix race when moving VIP during minor update

During a minor update of a controller node, we list the
VIP hosted on the node and we force them to move away
with a pcs command.

The way we call the pcs command is racy, so change the
action to make sure the VIP move is performed only if
the VIP is still hosted on the node when we run the action.

Change-Id: Id379f4fe1668d01fdd5f91b46e2f75d7cdb577ae
Closes-Bug: #1921351
'}]
commit_message:
HA: fix race when moving VIP during minor update

During a minor update of a controller node, we list the
VIP hosted on the node and we force them to move away
with a pcs command.

The way we call the pcs command is racy, so change the
action to make sure the VIP move is performed only if
the VIP is still hosted on the node when we run the action.

Change-Id: Id379f4fe1668d01fdd5f91b46e2f75d7cdb577ae
Closes-Bug: #1921351

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-01 06:08:38.000000000', 'message': 'Accept 142 as an exit code

In the same fashion we accepted 137 and 143 exit code status in
I8f19a80016a67ccad0371c5d108516aec640f031, we also accept 142.

It represents the SIGALRM exit status - it happens when podman reaches
the set timeout (currently 60s) when trying to cleanly stop a container.

Change-Id: I2d5f4e8c11384aeff3c0b1a2fdd5abb6a586522f
Closes-Bug: #1922179
Resolves: rhbz#1939910
'}]
commit_message:
Accept 142 as an exit code

In the same fashion we accepted 137 and 143 exit code status in
I8f19a80016a67ccad0371c5d108516aec640f031, we also accept 142.

It represents the SIGALRM exit status - it happens when podman reaches
the set timeout (currently 60s) when trying to cleanly stop a container.

Change-Id: I2d5f4e8c11384aeff3c0b1a2fdd5abb6a586522f
Closes-Bug: #1922179
Resolves: rhbz#1939910

commit_message:
Making devstack-plugin-(amqp1|kafka) branchless

The QA team pointed out to us that usually devstack plugins are
branchless [1] (and tagless but that's already the case here).

They haven't been branched since ussuri, we think that we simply
missed to retire them few series ago.

I think that's the right moment to do a little spring cleaning.
Let's drop these deliverables.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-April/021526.html

Change-Id: I7df2166cdd4b9266287d47d90c3cd49d6d122c71

messages: [{'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2021-04-04 08:10:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2021-04-07 05:31:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2021-04-07 13:07:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-04 08:10:20.000000000', 'message': "Don't update status for replaced resource

With I04e7ad90944c2d03ce0e59ba16af9d60d6e01222 we allowed
update of previously-existing resource if replacement
creation has failed during last update. However, we force
update the status of the existing resource to 'COMPLETE'.
Therefore, in the next update if properties/type has not
changed for the resource it won't try to update/replace
the previously existing resource resulting in false positive
of stack updated successfully.

Task: 42194
Change-Id: Icc90a921ec67e49aec2c4acfad72235c57c78421
(cherry picked from commit bfbaab107d709c37548a22239b952c6221b9ac85)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't update status for replaced resource

With I04e7ad90944c2d03ce0e59ba16af9d60d6e01222 we allowed
update of previously-existing resource if replacement
creation has failed during last update. However, we force
update the status of the existing resource to 'COMPLETE'.
Therefore, in the next update if properties/type has not
changed for the resource it won't try to update/replace
the previously existing resource resulting in false positive
of stack updated successfully.

Task: 42194
Change-Id: Icc90a921ec67e49aec2c4acfad72235c57c78421
(cherry picked from commit bfbaab107d709c37548a22239b952c6221b9ac85)

QA team pointed out to us that usually devstack plugins are
branchless [1] (and tagless but that's already the case here).

They haven't been branched since ussuri, we think that we simply
missed to retire them few series ago.

I think that's the right moment to do a little spring cleaning.
Let's drop these deliverables for Victoria/Wallaby.

Change-Id: I9310e604d1356d611f52164601095ba026a14b24

commit_message:
Making devstack-plugin-(amqp1|kafka) branchless

QA team pointed out to us that usually devstack plugins are
branchless [1] (and tagless but that's already the case here).

They haven't been branched since ussuri, we think that we simply
missed to retire them few series ago.

I think that's the right moment to do a little spring cleaning.
Let's drop these deliverables for Victoria/Wallaby.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-April/021526.html

Change-Id: I9310e604d1356d611f52164601095ba026a14b24

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: Id350e6146a7e548d35ceb6110387feb208169fed

[{'created': '2021-03-30 13:56:47.000000000', 'message': 'Set RBD default features based on distro

In some jobs, we run tests that use "rbd map".
On older kernels, this will not work if newer
RBD features are used.  (Specifically, fast-diff
on bionic.)

On older distros, enable fewer features by default.

Change-Id: Iff1c5210b0279379eb9612b206bdf456dd6f132e
'}, {'created': '2021-03-30 13:57:41.000000000', 'message': 'Set RBD default features based on distro

In some jobs, we run tests that use "rbd map".
On older kernels, this will not work if newer
RBD features are used.  (Specifically, fast-diff
on bionic.)

On older distros, enable fewer features by default.

Closes-Bug: #1921897
Change-Id: Iff1c5210b0279379eb9612b206bdf456dd6f132e
'}]
commit_message:
Set RBD default features based on distro

In some jobs, we run tests that use "rbd map".
On older kernels, this will not work if newer
RBD features are used.  (Specifically, fast-diff
on bionic.)

On older distros, enable fewer features by default.

Closes-Bug: #1921897
Change-Id: Iff1c5210b0279379eb9612b206bdf456dd6f132e

[{'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-03-29 04:30:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-03-29 04:33:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We need this migration to ensure that policy configuration follows the change in horizon.
Unfortunately I couldn't make this before Wallaby cut off but we definitely need to backport this to Wallaby since Horizon expects policy.yaml and default policies since Wallaby release."}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-03-30 12:50:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Note for reviewers

Policy files were generated by following the documentation[1] in Horizon.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/doc/source/contributor/topics/policy.rst#policy-file-maintenance

This documentation was created by the change in Horizon described in Depends-on.'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2021-04-05 20:39:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Looks very good Takashi. Since it's a big patch, I want to give it a second pass and also test on my environment to guarantee that main operations work well for Manila. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2021-04-05 20:50:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)

Few comments now, I'm going through the deprecated policies"}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2021-04-05 20:54:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2021-04-05 21:13:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Deprecated policies look good. I understand they are automatically generated from the policies we have in Manila, so we should update those yaml files everytime we modify policies in manila core, is that correct?'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-04-06 01:17:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Victoria,

Thank you for your review.

Please note that these yaml files are generated by oslo-policy-generator according to the guideline in Horizon, and I don't think it's a good idea to modify that.
If we need any fix in these content then I think we should fix the code in manila side so that we get the expected content."}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-04-06 01:48:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-04-06 01:49:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

seems like the policy files were generated from old manila code. I regenerated cotents with the latest manila. Please note that we still see missing descriptions because of current implementation in Manila.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-04-06 03:00:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2021-04-06 12:26:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Makes sense, thanks Takashi'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2021-04-06 22:52:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Thank you. This looks good to me, would like some Horizon folks to help review this.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2021-04-07 13:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thanks. This follows the instruction documented at https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/contributor/topics/policy.html#policy-file-maintenance'}]

[{'created': '2021-03-24 14:40:02.000000000', 'message': "IPMI: Handle vendor set boot device differences

Supermicro machines, when in UEFI mode, have a different
device number, in binary, to represent the hard disk from
other vendors such as Fujitsu which actually has somewhat
similar code in their driver.

This means we need to be somewhat cognizent of the vendor of
the BMC and possibly update the device mapping based upon that
vendor.

This may ultimately fix a number of IPMI related problems, because
there is a reliance upon the text output of ipmitool, which only
reads the bytes retured by the BMC, which may not be reality after

operating difference.

backport, where as off of the original change it was clean except git

commit_message:
IPMI: Handle vendor set boot device differences

Supermicro machines, when in UEFI mode, have a different
device number, in binary, to represent the hard disk from
other vendors such as Fujitsu which actually has somewhat
similar code in their driver.

This means we need to be somewhat cognizent of the vendor of
the BMC and possibly update the device mapping based upon that
vendor.

This may ultimately fix a number of IPMI related problems, because
there is a reliance upon the text output of ipmitool, which only
reads the bytes retured by the BMC, which may not be reality after
the next reset, espescialy if ipmitool doesn't know of the UEFI
operating difference.

NOTE: This had to be a direct cherry-pick from the original change
as the intermediate branch that we normally would have cherry-picked
from has had other changes made to it, which resulted in an unclean
backport, where as with the original change it was clean.

Change-Id: Ie19db9e0cf1eafdfc9bb46248f4d457337821f94
Story: 2008241
Task: 41085
(cherry picked from commit a7ac9ce8cd53fdebdf0d9aaeaf439da08a0b3ec8)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-18 08:13:46.000000000', 'message': "Configure ceph for glance if multiple stores is enabled

Glance has support to configure multiple stores from Stein release. Recently
support for configuring multiple filesystem stores for glance is added. In
this patch we are configuring ceph if both multiple stores is enabled
using 'GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True' and ceph is also
enabled.

In order to configure ceph with support to multiple stores using devstack
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True
enable_plugin devstack-plugin-ceph https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph
ENABLE_CEPH_GLANCE=True

NOTE: These changes are required as soon glance is set to remove single
store support in Victoria cycle.

Change-Id: I210e711aab742e005badc919ec040febb9f45f7f
"}, {'created': '2020-07-20 06:05:55.000000000', 'message': "Configure ceph for glance if multiple stores is enabled

Glance has support to configure multiple stores from Stein release. Recently
support for configuring multiple filesystem stores for glance is added. In
this patch we are configuring ceph if both multiple stores is enabled
using 'GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True' and ceph is also
enabled.

In order to configure ceph with support to multiple stores using devstack
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True
enable_plugin devstack-plugin-ceph https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph
ENABLE_CEPH_GLANCE=True

NOTE: These changes are required as soon glance is set to remove single
store support in Victoria cycle.

Change-Id: I210e711aab742e005badc919ec040febb9f45f7f
"}]
commit_message:
Configure ceph for glance if multiple stores is enabled

Glance has support to configure multiple stores from Stein release. Recently
support for configuring multiple filesystem stores for glance is added. In
this patch we are configuring ceph if both multiple stores is enabled
using 'GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True' and ceph is also
enabled.

In order to configure ceph with support to multiple stores using devstack
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True
enable_plugin devstack-plugin-ceph https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph
ENABLE_CEPH_GLANCE=True

NOTE: These changes are required as soon glance is set to remove single
store support in Victoria cycle.

Change-Id: I210e711aab742e005badc919ec040febb9f45f7f

Any clarity would be appreciated."}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2021-04-01 05:29:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1
> 
> (6 comments)
> 
> Thanks. I have some comments/concerns. I'd really like to see the release note changed at a minimum. A few items regarding documentation that could likely be handled later on, and I'm really confused why the ignore parameter is a value. Any clarity would be appreciated.

Hi Julia,
"ignore" parameter is a facility given by iLO so that if any customer wants to ignore the security status of the security parameter even if it is at risk. For Example: "security boot" is also one of the security parameter and not every customer may want to deploy in secure boot mode using ilo drivers so he can simply set the ignore as true for that parameter and then overall_security_status is turned to "Ignored" instead of "Risk".'}, {'account_id': 19604, 'date': '2021-04-05 15:49:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 19604, 'date': '2021-04-05 15:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Add security dashboard clean steps to ilo drivers

This commit adds new clean steps security_parameters_update,
update_minimum_password_length and update_auth_failure_logging_threshold
to allow users to edit following security parameters which fetched
during node inspection -
``Password_Complexity``, ``RequiredLoginForiLORBSU``,
``RequireHostAuthentication``, ``MinPasswordLength``,
``IPMI/DCMI_Over_LAN``, ``Authentication_failure_Logging``,
and ``Secure_Boot``.

Story: 2008024
Task: 40736
Change-Id: I0dd9a83ee23c6b846eda3ff171ab7b3138b22fa7

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35

"}, {'created': '2021-03-25 10:49:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix requirements issues

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I2f41e05df1cc978821bf7cb6d9a95bf543c7fba3
"}]
commit_message:
Fix requirements issues

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Herv√© Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I2f41e05df1cc978821bf7cb6d9a95bf543c7fba3

commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
gzip, not xz

xz may cause POST_FAILUREs due to memory pressure [1].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-April/021609.html

Change-Id: I2ea3175ecf2508b62640bfffdd798d7072e55550

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-02 03:47:25.000000000', 'message': "Don't update status for replaced resource

With I04e7ad90944c2d03ce0e59ba16af9d60d6e01222 we allowed
update of previously-existing resource if replacement
creation has failed during last update. However, we force
update the status of the existing resource to 'COMPLETE'.
Therefore, in the next update if properties/type has not
changed for the resource it won't try to update/replace
the previously existing resource resulting in false positive
of stack updated successfully.

Task: 42194
Change-Id: Icc90a921ec67e49aec2c4acfad72235c57c78421
(cherry picked from commit bfbaab107d709c37548a22239b952c6221b9ac85)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't update status for replaced resource

With I04e7ad90944c2d03ce0e59ba16af9d60d6e01222 we allowed
update of previously-existing resource if replacement
creation has failed during last update. However, we force
update the status of the existing resource to 'COMPLETE'.
Therefore, in the next update if properties/type has not
changed for the resource it won't try to update/replace
the previously existing resource resulting in false positive
of stack updated successfully.

Task: 42194
Change-Id: Icc90a921ec67e49aec2c4acfad72235c57c78421
(cherry picked from commit bfbaab107d709c37548a22239b952c6221b9ac85)

As someone who generally avoids wsman in favour of IPMI, I can see potential in this. There are a few concerns though:

* Users would have to configure both ipmi_* and drac_* in driver_info to benefit from additional functionality of the idrac hardware type. This is quite clunky.

* This would have been very welcome 2+ years ago, however are we now at a stage where we should be promoting redfish over IPMI?'}, {'account_id': 23847, 'date': '2021-02-11 16:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6: Code-Review-2
> 
> What's the point of doing this? You can similarly claim that the iDRAC hardware type supports SNMP, fake, etc. The point of having redfish interfaces in iDRAC is that iDRAC is building on top of them (Redfish is highly extensible).
> 
> Users who need to use IPMI with Dell hardware can just use the IPMI hardware type.

The Dell EMC integrated Dell Remote Access Controller (iDRAC) hardware supports the IPMI, Redfish, and WS-Man protocols. They can all be used at the same time. This change would complete the promise of making the idrac hardware type the one-stop driver for managing Dell EMC systems with an iDRAC. That journey was first described by the approved specification https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/src/branch/master/specs/approved/idrac-support-of-redfish-interfaces.rst. Please note its statement in the Solution section:

"Implementing the solution in the idrac hardware type contributes toward making it the one Dell EMC driver for its bare metal servers with iDRACs and their value added implementations of the IPMI, Redfish, and WS-Man management protocols."

The initial change associated with that specification added support for Redfish hardware interface implementations. This adds IPMI.

With this change, an operator/user could configure a node managing a Dell EMC system with an iDRAC to use a mix of hardware interfaces which rely on different management protocols, including IPMI. Customers have asked if we could add IPMI, because they have a need for such a mix. More recently, during last year's OpenDev Hardware Automation virtual event, we learned a large number of operators continue to rely on IPMI.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-02-11 16:16:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> This change would complete the promise of making the idrac hardware type the one-stop driver

Without a compelling user story behind this, I don't believe it's a compelling goal to follow. This patch will definitely add confusing since it will create two equivalent ways of doing the same thing.

We did this for Redfish, because Redfish is the path forward for both Ironic and Dell, AND because Dell can and will build additional features on top of it. I don't see this future for IPMI."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-02-11 16:27:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-2

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> > This change would complete the promise of making the idrac hardware type the one-stop driver
> 
> Without a compelling user story behind this, I don't believe it's a compelling goal to follow. This patch will definitely add confusing since it will create two equivalent ways of doing the same thing.
> 
> We did this for Redfish, because Redfish is the path forward for both Ironic and Dell, AND because Dell can and will build additional features on top of it. I don't see this future for IPMI.

I concur with Dmitry, and this is kind of contrary to what I've been hearing from larger operators. They want a generic entry path which will generally work and switch to a specific driver automatically to meet more complex needs or vendor quarks. Requiring greater specific information such as actually knowing the hardware type upfront when they are a multi-vendor shop actually hurts them in terms of user experience as it requires additional information and context for every single that Data Center operations racks and System Ops goes to enroll in ironic. Since... separation of duties and information compartmentalization is a huge thing as well.

To make this worse, Everything I hear from operators is about the elimination of all IPMI because of the security issues baked into the design coupled with the prevalence of rainbow tables and GPU performance to try and calculate hash values."}, {'account_id': 7160, 'date': '2021-02-15 20:23:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Team,
I am do not understand this response.
On the last opendev HW days meeting we got feedback from operators.
See https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/OpenDev_HardwareAutomation_Day2 lines 262-290.
While I agree that we want operators to move to redfish for many reasons,
it is very clear that many of them still use IPMI.
This patch is response to it.

Since people already reviewed it unless there is technical issue with the code I see no reason to block it.'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2021-02-16 08:37:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I struggle to follow the strong opposition to this change:

- there seems to be consensus that Redfish is where everyone wants to go (the ongoing work mostly driven by the same team proposing this patch should be proof of that);
- IPMI has its weaknesses but it is still the prevalent protocol in data centers and will be for the foreseeable future (while some may wish for something else, there is little incentive, e.g. a killer feature relevant IRL, to trigger a massive move);
- I would think that operators with different hardware solutions prefer the generic IPMI driver and expect this works across their hardware, so they use the generic IPMI driver (like we do, for instance), and this change does not take this option away;
- other operators with a more uniform park or with a preference for vendor provided software, e.g. due to the support they expect or to facilitate the move from one protocol to another, may want to go with this option, and I do not see a good reason why we should prevent them from doing this.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-02-16 09:03:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

We already have the IPMI hardware type, it's not going anyway. Our consumers will not benefit from another option they have to understand that does exactly the same thing.

At the very least, the commit message for this change must explain how the *operators* benefit from it, not what is possible to do (otherwise you need to add SNMP and fake as well)."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-02-16 09:15:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Another minimum requirement for this patch to even be considered is to get rid of idrac-ipmi. We have idrac-redfish because we reasonably expect non-standard iDRAC (as is the case with idrac-redfish-virtual-media). I don't think we expect iDRAC IPMI additions, nor do I think we should have them even if possible. You need to use plain ipmi implementations (I'm not saying I'll start liking the patch after that, but without the 2 changes I've requested it's a clear no-go)."}, {'account_id': 23847, 'date': '2021-02-17 21:41:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thank you for your comment, Mark.

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> As someone who generally avoids wsman in favour of IPMI, I can see potential in this. There are a few concerns though:
> 
> * Users would have to configure both ipmi_* and drac_* in driver_info to benefit from additional functionality of the idrac hardware type. This is quite clunky.
> 

While I agree having to configure both ipmi_* and drac_* in driver_info is awkward, the hardware interface implementations presently rely on those settings. Changing that approach would touch much more code. I am open to considering simplifying this as a follow-on change after we have discussed it within the Ironic community and with our operators/users. This may be a good topic for the next Project Teams Gathering (PTG).

> * This would have been very welcome 2+ years ago, however are we now at a stage where we should be promoting redfish over IPMI?

A couple of years ago, my thinking was similar to yours today, will not Redfish soon be the preferred protocol? Should we not be promoting it over IPMI? Is not IPMI on the way out? Therefore, why add IPMI support to the idrac hardware type? Is not that ironic üòä

Until this past summer, I continued to believe that. However, the OpenDev Hardware Automation virtual event in July 2020 changed my mind. There we heard from a large number of operators that they continue to use IPMI. And many use a mix of IPMI and Redfish or IPMI, Redfish, and vendor [1][2].

As I wrote in the approved specification for adding Redfish support to the idrac hardware type, having it support all three (3) management protocols -- IPMI, Redfish, and WS-Man -- can help operators on their varied journeys to adopt Redfish [3]. It seems to me that is a way of promoting Redfish.

Better "late", then never!?

[1] https://superuser.openstack.org/articles/opendev-hardware-automation-recap-and-next-steps/, Day 2, Part Two: Bare Metal Infrastructure
[2] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/OpenDev_HardwareAutomation_Day2, lines 258-320
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/src/branch/master/specs/approved/idrac-support-of-redfish-interfaces.rst, Introduction, Proposed change's Background, Goal, and Non-goals subsections'}, {'account_id': 23847, 'date': '2021-02-18 01:16:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> We already have the IPMI hardware type, it's not going anyway. Our consumers will not benefit from another option they have to understand that does exactly the same thing.
> 

I respectfully disagree that our consumers will not benefit from this change. They will benefit, because Dell Technologies

* will continue to fulfill the responsibility it has on account of its vendor idrac driver being in-tree, operating and maintaining an ironic third-party CI that tests proposed ironic code changes against the idrac driver, including its newly supported IPMI hardware interfaces, and Dell EMC servers
* supports its customers and ironic consumers who use the idrac hardware type with its Dell EMC bare metal products

> At the very least, the commit message for this change must explain how the *operators* benefit from it, not what is possible to do (otherwise you need to add SNMP and fake as well).

To address this concern, I propose we include a reference to the sections of the previously approved specification for adding Redfish support to the idrac hardware type [1]. TL;DR, those describe how its support of all three (3) management protocols -- IPMI, Redfish, and WS-Man -- can help operators on their varied journeys to adopt Redfish. From what we learned from operators during last summer's virtual OpenDev Hardware Automation event, they are long way from completing them [2][3].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/src/branch/master/specs/approved/idrac-support-of-redfish-interfaces.rst, Introduction, Proposed change's Background, Goal, and Non-goals subsections
[2] https://superuser.openstack.org/articles/opendev-hardware-automation-recap-and-next-steps/, Day 2, Part Two: Bare Metal Infrastructure
[3] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/OpenDev_HardwareAutomation_Day2, lines 258-320"}, {'account_id': 23847, 'date': '2021-02-18 01:47:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> Another minimum requirement for this patch to even be considered is to get rid of idrac-ipmi. We have idrac-redfish because we reasonably expect non-standard iDRAC (as is the case with idrac-redfish-virtual-media).

We believe supporting the existing ipmitool*, instead of idrac-ipmi*, would be more confusing to our consumers, rather than less. Consistency can help alleviate confusion here; think idrac-ipmi*, idrac-redfish*, and idrac-wsman*. If the existing ipmitool* were supported, operators would become confused and try to use the reference redfish* with the idrac hardware type and not understand why they cannot.

> I don't think we expect iDRAC IPMI additions, nor do I think we should have them even if possible. You need to use plain ipmi implementations (I'm not saying I'll start liking the patch after that, but without the 2 changes I've requested it's a clear no-go).

Dell Technologies values its customers. If they have requirements which would require changes to the IPMI hardware interface implementations, we would listen and seriously consider meeting them. We are flexible and responsive to the needs of their businesses. While we promote the use of Redfish, it is clear their journeys are varied. The idrac-ipmi* interface implementations are where iDRAC-specific IPMI changes would be made."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-02-18 07:31:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> Team,
> I am do not understand this response.
> On the last opendev HW days meeting we got feedback from operators.
> See https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/OpenDev_HardwareAutomation_Day2 lines 262-290.

True, The audience was very mixed on that session. There is also an high level disconnect in that some people just use IPMI for referring to anything to do with a BMC. I couldn't help but wonder if that was some of what was occurring on that call, but c'est la vie.. One market vertical that seemed minimal on that call was Telecoms. I have yet to talk to a telecom that *wants* IPMI. Actually, I take that back. I think one did say they would settle for it because it was the "known evil" as opposed to the "unknown newcomer redfish". 

> While I agree that we want operators to move to redfish for many reasons,
> it is very clear that many of them still use IPMI.

Agreed, even when they shouldn't, but they are seeking the common denominator, which is what drives to them trying the most generic, community supported path.

> This patch is response to it.
> 
> Since people already reviewed it unless there is technical issue with the code I see no reason to block it.

Unfortunately there is a perception differential issue that needs to be resolved, or at least an understanding reached which is the mutually agreeable happy path. If the modules were doing special things on top, it would be a totally different discussion, but what they are doing is stamping a label on the existing community supported code and drivers. That creates a support expectation through that declaration. This also creates likelyhood for tool breakages or custom operator scripting if someone tries to navigate this specifically. I guess my frustration is we keep making ironic harder to use through actions like this, when we should be hiding as much as possible from the users in terms of special details, and finding a happy path in the community on such issues seem to be the greatest challenge. Granted, the Dell perception is likely "Everyone should just use the idrac hardware type" which increases the bar for use in general, but at the same time as an hardware vendor, that aligns well. :)'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-02-18 07:45:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> Another minimum requirement for this patch to even be considered is to get rid of idrac-ipmi. We have idrac-redfish because we reasonably expect non-standard iDRAC (as is the case with idrac-redfish-virtual-media). I don't think we expect iDRAC IPMI additions, nor do I think we should have them even if possible. You need to use plain ipmi implementations (I'm not saying I'll start liking the patch after that, but without the 2 changes I've requested it's a clear no-go).

I read Arne's comments, and I'm a little more willing, but I'm expecting support cases at some point where someone is trying to use this with idrac_username and idrac_password, and it makes me want to actually work towards eliminating all of the various driver specific names. Kind of also going to Mark's comment. Granted, I think the last time I tried floating we work to simplify/unify/make consistent the credential settings, I felt like I was about to face a guillotine with the community feedback that I got. Granted, that was also like ?2 or 2.5? years ago.

At the end of the day, I think it all comes down to what is reasonably expected, and unfortunately too many people I talk to just expect "ipmi" and "redfish" to just work. I'd rather just shunt operators off the generic drivers if they start asking for features that the hardware doesn't support or is incompatible with.

Thinking about consistency, we have a driver that explicitly declared ipmitool as a supported interface (irmc) and ilo also falls back to the ipmi interface code in some cases. Special casing a wrapper just doesn't seem right to me without a technical reason behind it.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-02-18 08:13:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(4 comments)

[trim]
> > * Users would have to configure both ipmi_* and drac_* in driver_info to benefit from additional functionality of the idrac hardware type. This is quite clunky.
> > 
> 
> While I agree having to configure both ipmi_* and drac_* in driver_info is awkward, the hardware interface implementations presently rely on those settings. Changing that approach would touch much more code. I am open to considering simplifying this as a follow-on change after we have discussed it within the Ironic community and with our operators/users. This may be a good topic for the next Project Teams Gathering (PTG).
> 

We've not started an etherpad, and it is that time of the season!

Seriously though, I think we should go do down this path. I floated doing this a couple years back and got a lot of pushback, but it seems like people are far more onboard with doing this. 


> > * This would have been very welcome 2+ years ago, however are we now at a stage where we should be promoting redfish over IPMI?
> 
> A couple of years ago, my thinking was similar to yours today, will not Redfish soon be the preferred protocol? Should we not be promoting it over IPMI? Is not IPMI on the way out? Therefore, why add IPMI support to the idrac hardware type? Is not that ironic üòä
> 
> Until this past summer, I continued to believe that. However, the OpenDev Hardware Automation virtual event in July 2020 changed my mind. There we heard from a large number of operators that they continue to use IPMI. And many use a mix of IPMI and Redfish or IPMI, Redfish, and vendor [1][2].
> 

I contend that the attendance was skewed, but it is in the past. What is interesting though that I'm not hearing an ask at all for IPMI outside of the operators that see it as "the evil we know" as opposed to "that new redfish thing we don't know". I wish I was making up those statements, but it does highlight a larger perception issue that operators have with interacting with their BMCs. Maybe another topic for the PTG.

> As I wrote in the approved specification for adding Redfish support to the idrac hardware type, having it support all three (3) management protocols -- IPMI, Redfish, and WS-Man -- can help operators on their varied journeys to adopt Redfish [3]. It seems to me that is a way of promoting Redfish.
> 

Except the specification, while floating the overall idea, would have been interpreted as just using the existing interfaces, not wrapping the existing interface with an idrac name.


> Better "late", then never!?
> 

True, even though it was a non-goal of the spec. The bottom line is there seems to be consensus if the existing interface name is used (i.e. not the idrac-ipmi alias this patch creates), and there is more clarity as to how this helps the operators, then the overall theme seems totally valid/acceptable and ultimately awesome. I would just prefer that we also discuss ironic/drivers/drac.py's declaration ordering since it seems mismatched and will actually create a mismatched driver if someone creates a node relying upon just the hardware type and the enabled_hardware_types settings. Posting comments on that should be along with this comment.

> [1] https://superuser.openstack.org/articles/opendev-hardware-automation-recap-and-next-steps/, Day 2, Part Two: Bare Metal Infrastructure
> [2] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/OpenDev_HardwareAutomation_Day2, lines 258-320
> [3] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/src/branch/master/specs/approved/idrac-support-of-redfish-interfaces.rst, Introduction, Proposed change's Background, Goal, and Non-goals subsections'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-02-18 08:36:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(14 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-02-18 09:12:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> We believe supporting the existing ipmitool*, instead of idrac-ipmi*, would be more confusing to our consumers, rather than less.

You're adding a new label to the existing implementation. We accepted that for Redfish (I didn't feel easy about it) because we expected vendor changes. This does not apply here.

> Consistency can help alleviate confusion here; think idrac-ipmi*, idrac-redfish*, and idrac-wsman*

Consistency is an argument that can work in many directions. idrac-wsman is unrelated here: it's another implementation. idrac-redfish* may (and does) include Dell specific code. idrac-ipmi is just an alias that operators need to understand.

If we could use one set of credentials, it would be another conversation. I've been long thinking of unifying username/password, but the address is problematic in general case. If Dell could solve that so that all idrac-* implementations use *only* drac_* credentials, I would look at this proposal with a bigger interest.

Even then, we need a community-level agreement, because we'll have to change all IPMI-compatible drivers to do the same (consistency, as you rightfully noticed)."}, {'account_id': 7160, 'date': '2021-02-18 14:42:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> > Patch Set 6:
> > 
> > Team,
> > I am do not understand this response.
> > On the last opendev HW days meeting we got feedback from operators.
> > See https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/OpenDev_HardwareAutomation_Day2 lines 262-290.
> 
> True, The audience was very mixed on that session. There is also an high level disconnect in that some people just use IPMI for referring to anything to do with a BMC. I couldn't help but wonder if that was some of what was occurring on that call, but c'est la vie.. One market vertical that seemed minimal on that call was Telecoms. I have yet to talk to a telecom that *wants* IPMI. Actually, I take that back. I think one did say they would settle for it because it was the "known evil" as opposed to the "unknown newcomer redfish". 
> 
> > While I agree that we want operators to move to redfish for many reasons,
> > it is very clear that many of them still use IPMI.
> 
> Agreed, even when they shouldn't, but they are seeking the common denominator, which is what drives to them trying the most generic, community supported path.
> 
> > This patch is response to it.
> > 
> > Since people already reviewed it unless there is technical issue with the code I see no reason to block it.
> 
> Unfortunately there is a perception differential issue that needs to be resolved, or at least an understanding reached which is the mutually agreeable happy path. If the modules were doing special things on top, it would be a totally different discussion, but what they are doing is stamping a label on the existing community supported code and drivers. That creates a support expectation through that declaration. This also creates likelyhood for tool breakages or custom operator scripting if someone tries to navigate this specifically. I guess my frustration is we keep making ironic harder to use through actions like this, when we should be hiding as much as possible from the users in terms of special details, and finding a happy path in the community on such issues seem to be the greatest challenge. Granted, the Dell perception is likely "Everyone should just use the idrac hardware type" which increases the bar for use in general, but at the same time as an hardware vendor, that aligns well. :)

After extensive validation it was determined that no changes, extensions on top of base module is needed. If they are needed they will be here and not impact generic module that is used for all vendors.'}, {'account_id': 32108, 'date': '2021-02-22 16:21:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 14629, 'date': '2021-02-22 16:22:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(29 comments)

Yogesh, thank you very much for the proposed change. Nice progress!

I have reviewed the documentation and code changes. However, I have not yet taken a look at the commit message, unit tests, nor release note.

My most substantive comments are:

1. It would be clearer if the new interfaces were named idrac-ipmitool*, instead of idrac-ipmi, because it communicates they are based on the ipmitool implementations.
2. Determine if the iDRAC supports the IPMI socat console, and, if so, declare iDRAC driver support of it.
3. Investigate if the Shell In A Box console hardware interface implementation should define get_properties() and validate().

Please see additional comments in line.'}, {'account_id': 32108, 'date': '2021-02-25 14:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 14629, 'date': '2021-02-25 14:36:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

It would be a different situation if there was a reason to have code in the driver for slight differences. Like, intel-ipmitool has at least some code to help justify *why* the class exists. It is only 84 lines, but it still enables a specific use pattern.

I guess, the practical question becomes will there be code? Is there code planned? Is there an identified need, or is this all based on just perception and perception management?'}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2021-03-27 21:21:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

For 3rd party CI contact info: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems/DellEMC_Ironic_CI'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-03-30 18:11:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: -Code-Review

So I had a long chat with Richard.

I'm removing my -2 at this time as some aspects *have* changed. There are now doc strings describing the delineation and use reasoning of the classes. Which is a good first step for legitimate and logical delineation *in this case*.

I'm not happy that we're just not adding the base IPMI interfaces and duplicating them, but it does seem from the discussion with Richard is that there is serious discussion underway of improving their ipmi support where it may require specific classes to handle vendor specific overrides which wouldn't be appropriate for the community driver. When factoring those two aspects together, the case can be made that the duplicate classes are a good thing in terms of support deprecation and ensuring a clean user experience with-in the idrac hardware type. Crossing between hardware types being more problematic, but a somewhat more operational problem for which a reset flag exists today.

Granted, the alternative with migrating is detecting the vendor, and embedding logic to make interfaces changes dynamically, but that is also problematic for operators using declarative configuration management. Even though, I'd personally kind of prefer some capability of that to handle vendor support fragmentation, but that is a headache unrelated to this specific change.

Richard noted on the call that he does owe us some revisions in terms of docs/release notes, and commit message wording, and as such I'm not leaving a review a this point as I expect additional minor changes to be made soon."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-03-31 12:10:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

I'm still not sold on this, and I don't think my mind will change (although we'll talk later today). More thoughts on topic:

1) There is a precedent of re-using IPMI interfaces in non-IPMI hardware types: https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/branch/master/ironic/drivers/irmc.py#L57

2) Reusing existing interfaces have some small but nice upsides, for example you can use default_power_interface=ipmi if you need it for some reason.

3) On the other hand, we have an unfortunately precedent with iLO and iRMC subclassing iPXE and PXE boot interfaces. We already got a problem with default_boot_interface=ipxe in metal3 because of it.

4) If that's what we do, we need to do it with all hardware types supporting IPMI (so, iRMC, iLO, iBMC). This is going to lead to an explosion of entry points and make configuration really hard.

5) We, as the community, already suffer from perceptions issues. We're seen as unnecessary complicated and hard to use. This may be more serious than you think, and this change will inevitably contribute to that."}, {'account_id': 23847, 'date': '2021-04-06 09:58:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

I had an extended discussion with Dmitry. Thank you, Dmitry :) While he seems to be on board with adding IPMI support to the idrac driver, he is concerned about the proposed names for the hardware interface implementations, idrac-ipmitool*. He feels those names might cause confusion for ironic‚Äôs consumers around how they differ from the existing ipmitool*, since they are proposed to only have a different name. Such confusion could be perceived as additional complexity among users who already feel ironic is too complicated. While I share Dmitry‚Äôs concern about adding complexity to ironic, in this case, I wonder if the opposite is true. Could it actually reduce complexity?

After reflecting on Dmitry‚Äôs feedback, I am unclear how this could cause confusion for our consumers who already use the idrac hardware type. They are familiar with the pattern established when we added Redfish support to idrac, idrac-redfish* and idrac-wsman*. And if ipmitool* was supported, they might become confused about why they cannot use redfish* or the redfish driver with Dell EMC systems. ‚Äúidrac supports ipmitool*, Ironic supports Redfish, and iDRAC supports Redfish. Therefore, I should be able to use the redfish driver with Dell EMC systems. Right?‚Äù

And, if plain old ipmitool* were supported by the idrac driver, what would happen if an adaptation had to be made to one of those hardware interface implementations to enable it to continue to work with iDRAC or we wanted to extend its functionality? A new name would have to be introduced, which would be a breaking change for idrac driver users.

To avoid such a breaking change, the approved ‚ÄúDefine idrac Hardware Type Support of Redfish Interfaces‚Äù specification [1] described a solution [2]:

‚ÄúNew idrac-redfish entry points are defined by new Python classes, because using the generic, vendor-independent Redfish classes would make the redfish entry points synonyms for idrac-redfish and supported. A later requirement to change the name of an entry point's Python class to resolve a Dell EMC-specific incompatibility or introduce vendor value added, which would eliminate support for redfish, could be a breaking change. The new Python classes are derived from the generic, vendor-independent Redfish classes.‚Äù

The same applies to adding IPMI support to the idrac driver today.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/src/branch/master/specs/approved/idrac-support-of-redfish-interfaces.rst
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/src/branch/master/specs/approved/idrac-support-of-redfish-interfaces.rst#solution"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-04-06 11:06:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> They are familiar with the pattern established when we added Redfish support to idrac, idrac-redfish* and idrac-wsman*

No, it's not. I would like us to stop returning to this argument. With Redfish we envisioned significant changes in vendor drivers since the beginning, and this has come true: only the idrac-redfish power interface does not carry any differences (maybe vendor too, but there is a clear space for extensions there). This is more similar to the iLO driver, which is either the older protocol or Redfish with extensions under the hood, not to IPMI.

So to answer your earlier question: no, it cannot lead to reduced confusion. Having several ways to doing the same thing never do, and you won't be able to sell it to users.

> And if ipmitool* was supported, they might become confused about why they cannot use redfish* or the redfish driver with Dell EMC systems

This is a very good question. I've previously suggested a way out of it, and you've rejected it. If you ever change your mind, I'll be very happy, but it's by no means an argument for doing the same thing with IPMI.

Also: Redfish and IPMI situation are different.

> what would happen if an adaptation had to be made to one of those hardware interface implementations to enable it to continue to work with iDRAC

A fix for this MUST happen in the main IPMI driver. If I hadn't had -2 here before, I would put it right now: "we may break the IPMI hardware type" is a horrible thing to happen for many reasons, one of biggest is that the consumers tend to treat IPMI as something that always works.

Even if you fix Ironic by demanding that everyone using Dell switches to your driver (a potential PR disaster for your company btw), 1) not everyone will, 2) not everyone will even learn about it, 3) you'll break upgrades, 4) you'll break everything that uses IPMI, including e.g. fencing in RH OSP and RHEL tools. The reality of this change would be ipmitool itself fixing the compatibility, so no changes would be required in Ironic.

And keep in mind that some of us are nearly done supporting Newton and will support Queens for a long time. "Fixes" by introducing new interfaces will never reach these old versions that people still use.'}, {'account_id': 7160, 'date': '2021-04-06 17:22:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+1

I thought that we already agreed that we have a generic driver (for ipmi, redfish, etc.) that can be used by any vendor that may or may not work for all HW. Vendor drivers inherit that common implementation and do any vendor specific fixes and extensions as needed. That ensure that a fix for one vendor is done in vendor specific code and does not break common code usage for other vendors.
That avoid a situation that we encountered at https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic/+/784156.
That also allows for vendor lists their support for various protocols and makes compatibility matrix https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic/+/733716 clean and real.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-04-06 17:26:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> That avoid a situation that we encountered

No, it wouldn't. We would still try to fix SuperMicro, and the iDRAC driver would inherit the problem from the generic code."}, {'account_id': 7160, 'date': '2021-04-06 17:32:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

We should NOT have vendor specific code in generic driver.
This is what vendor drivers are for.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-04-06 23:24:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> Patch Set 14:
> 
> We should NOT have vendor specific code in generic driver.
> This is what vendor drivers are for.

I can see your point and even somewhat agree to it from your point of view, however I'll offer a counterpoint.

Let us ask ourselves what is ipmitool. My perception is that it is an IPMI client which is vendor aware and has some magical knowledge baked in to understand *how* to navigate certain states in vendors.  Granted, it is also no longer released upstream. Downstream maintainers only backport what they feel is needful. Looking at the ipmitool source, there is Dell specific code in it. While not a ton, there is some specific parameter handling code along with an ipmi_delloem library. Plus, there is a variation to handle Sensor data differences for HP hardware in the stock sensor parsing code. And intel specific code in lanplus.c Not as much as I was expecting, but it is still definitely there.

So I think we can't really compare situations *nor* treat this as an absolute when the underlying layer is *not* an absolute to begin with.

Then there is the other aspect, which is drivers and inclusion. If the community agrees with a model of every specific thing needs to be specifically delineated, we would need to throw out the third party CI concept as it was originally baked into the project. Maybe it is time we do that, but that also seems somewhat extreme. We have to maintain a generally beneficial path for those adopting new. We also can't necessarily tell everyone "upgrade, we'll only support you on the newest version where you special vendor case is accounted only in a separate driver. That is just operator unfriendly unless we automatically have code to shunt to vendor specific driver code. Of course, the *advantage* with third party CI is early detection of issues and to ensure a better/consistent operator or user experience which in theory should result in a lower maintenance costs for support later on.

So I have a radical solution... which may actually make everyone happy (or not). Forbid sub-classing of code that interacts with hardware. Yes, this means copying code and tests instead. At the same time, I don't think that is going to cease the small tiny variation fixes along the lines of what I see in ipmitool itself... as things of that nature still need to be backport-able. But it would isolate drivers into what they support.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-04-07 10:06:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> We should NOT have vendor specific code in generic driver

I really, really want to support this statement. But as Julia elaborated, this is simply not the world we live in. Circling back to something I said much earlier (maybe in the previous discussion): operators want us clearly understandable ways to interact with Ironic. If Dell says "this server supports Redfish and IPMI" and Ironic says "this driver talks Redfish / IPMI", these two have to work together. The situation with idrac-redfish-virtual-media is bad enough (and we get frustration on the customer end already).

Something I mentioned to Richard in private which I'm going to repeat in public: we're struggling to win the perception battle. OpenStack overall and Ironic specifically are perceived as hard to use, heavy, outdated. With Redfish gaining popularity people start to assume they can implement something quickly in their language of choice (Go anyone?) instead of reusing battle-tested and established solution. In the end, if Ironic loses, we all lose. If instead of one Ironic we have many smaller projects written in a bunch of languages, operators will lose in consistency, and you will lose in ability to provide added value for your hardware.

Julia sent an email a few months ago that highlights this issue very well, and to which none of you unfortunately responded. We need to move towards configuration with less friction if we want to keep mindshare. We need understand how operators phrase their requests, which is honestly "I have this server model and these operational requirements, figure it out". We're very far away from "figure it out", and adding more explicit choices does not help.

And if you envision the need for your IPMI additions, but cannot share them with the public yet, let's postpone this discussion until you can?'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-04-07 12:42:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

It has been an interesting discussion so far, and I think I managed to come up with an idea that satisfies all listed requirements: https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2008804. Please read and let me know what you think. If implemented, it will allow using generic names while keeping a possibility open for potential vendor changes.'}]

commit_message:
Add idrac HW type IPMI interface support

This change adds initial idrac hardware type support of interface
implementations vendor-independent IPMI hardware interface
implementations and are compatible with the integrated Dell
Remote Access Controller (iDRAC) baseboard management controller
(BMC), presently those of the management,console,vendorpassthrough
and power hardware interfaces. They are named `idrac-ipmi`.

The idrac hardware type declares support for those new interface
implementations, in addition to all interface implementations it has
been supporting. The priority order of supported interfaces remains
the same.

Story: 2008528
Task: 41609
Change-Id: I241c830167752014835845cb32663514220a9996

commit_message:
Add separated CA cert for etcd and front-proxy

Support creating different for k8s, etcd and front-proxy for
security hardening. We're following some best practices[1][2] but
adjusted based on the current Magnum deployment approach.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/best-practices/certificates/
[2] https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/kubeadm/kubeadm-certs/

Task: 40687
Story: 2008031

Change-Id: I523a4a85867f82d234ba1f3e6fad8b8cd2291182

subject: CentOS Stream 8: Use /usr/bin/which instead of bash function
messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2021-04-06 13:10:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-04-06 13:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Review-Priority+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2021-04-06 18:30:52.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to centos-stream'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2021-04-07 08:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-06 13:10:02.000000000', 'message': "CentOS Stream 8: Use /usr/bin/which instead of bash function

A bug has been introduced to the which package in CentOS Stream 8 which
causes it to fail when used with the following bash options:

set -u
set -o pipefail

Then, when running which we see the following output:

environment: line 1: _declare: unbound variable

As found by Pierre, this seems to be caused by the implementation of
which as a bash function which references an unbound variable
(_declare). It's tracked in Fedora by
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1944877#.

This change works around the issue by using the /usr/bin/which binary.

Co-Authored-By: Pierre Riteau <pierre@stackhpc.com>

Change-Id: I468d4e0460c13791b9f01d5854ef45472528c6fe
Story: 2008795
Task: 42215
"}]
commit_message:
CentOS Stream 8: Use /usr/bin/which instead of bash function

A bug has been introduced to the which package in CentOS Stream 8 which
causes it to fail when used with the following bash options:

set -u
set -o pipefail

Then, when running which we see the following output:

environment: line 1: _declare: unbound variable

As found by Pierre, this seems to be caused by the implementation of
which as a bash function which references an unbound variable
(_declare). It's tracked in Fedora by
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1944877#.

This change works around the issue by using the /usr/bin/which binary.

Co-Authored-By: Pierre Riteau <pierre@stackhpc.com>

Change-Id: I468d4e0460c13791b9f01d5854ef45472528c6fe
Story: 2008795
Task: 42215
